canonical_explanation.text: Radioactivity is the spontaneous emission of radiation from unstable nuclei, discovered by Becquerel. Three types of emissions exist: alpha particles (helium nuclei, +2 charge, least penetrating), beta particles (electrons, -1 charge, moderate penetration), and gamma rays (electromagnetic radiation, no charge, most penetrating). Half-life is the time for half the nuclei to decay. Nuclear fission is splitting of heavy nuclei (e.g., U-235) releasing energy and neutrons, used in nuclear reactors. Nuclear fusion is combining light nuclei (e.g., hydrogen to helium), the source of solar energy. Nuclear energy has applications in power generation and medicine, but poses hazards including radiation effects and waste disposal challenges.
rules: Radioactivity: spontaneous emission from unstable nuclei
Alpha particles: helium nuclei (2p, 2n), charge +2e, mass 4u
Beta particles: high-speed electrons, charge -e, mass ~0
Gamma rays: electromagnetic radiation, no charge, no mass
Half-life: time for half the nuclei to decay
Nuclear fission: heavy nucleus splits into lighter nuclei
Chain reaction: neutrons from fission cause more fissions
Nuclear fusion: light nuclei combine to form heavier nucleus
E = mc^2: mass converted to energy in nuclear reactions

questions.question_text: Radioactivity was discovered by:
questions.explanation_correct: Radioactivity was discovered by Becquerel in 1896, when he found that uranium salts emitted their own invisible and penetrating rays, without any external stimulus. This discovery of spontaneous radioactivity was a major breakthrough in our understanding of atomic structure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect. Rutherford is known for his famous gold foil experiment that discovered the atomic nucleus, but he did not discover radioactivity. Marie Curie and her husband Pierre Curie extensively studied radioactivity and coined the term, but they did not make the initial discovery. Einstein is famous for his theories of relativity, but he did not discover radioactivity.

questions.question_text: Alpha particles are:
questions.explanation_correct: Alpha particles are helium nuclei, which have a positive charge of +2. This makes them the heaviest and least penetrating type of radiation emitted from radioactive materials.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Alpha particles are not electrons, protons, or neutrons. Electrons have a negative charge, protons have a positive charge, and neutrons have no charge. Alpha particles are actually the nuclei of helium atoms, which are much heavier and less penetrating than these other subatomic particles.

questions.question_text: Beta particles are:
questions.explanation_correct: Beta particles are high-speed electrons emitted from the nucleus during radioactive decay, which is why option C is correct.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Beta particles are not helium nuclei (option A), protons (option B), or neutrons (option D). Helium nuclei are called alpha particles, protons are a different subatomic particle, and neutrons are also a different particle. Beta particles are specifically high-speed electrons released during radioactive decay.

questions.question_text: Gamma rays are:
questions.explanation_correct: Gamma rays are a type of electromagnetic radiation, which means they have no electric charge. This makes them the most penetrating type of radiation, able to pass through matter more easily than alpha or beta particles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gamma rays are not positively charged particles (option A) or negatively charged particles (option B). They are also not neutral particles (option D) - they are a form of electromagnetic radiation, just like visible light or microwaves. Only option C, 'electromagnetic radiation', correctly describes the nature of gamma rays.

questions.question_text: Which has the highest penetrating power?
questions.explanation_correct: Gamma rays have the highest penetrating power among the three types of radiation. This is because they have no electric charge, unlike alpha and beta particles, allowing them to pass through matter more easily.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gamma rays have the highest penetrating power because they are a form of electromagnetic radiation, which can travel through matter without being significantly absorbed or scattered. Alpha particles, being helium nuclei, have a positive charge and are easily stopped by even a thin layer of material. Beta particles, being high-energy electrons, have moderate penetrating power but are still less penetrating than gamma rays.

questions.question_text: Which has the highest ionizing power?
questions.explanation_correct: Alpha particles have the highest ionizing power among the three types of radiation. This is because alpha particles are the heaviest and most charged of the three, allowing them to easily knock electrons off atoms they encounter, creating more ion pairs along their path.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gamma rays, although highly penetrating, have the lowest ionizing power. This is because gamma rays are just high-energy electromagnetic radiation, which do not directly interact with atoms in the same way as charged particles like alpha and beta. Alpha particles, being the heaviest and most charged, have the highest ionizing power and can cause the most damage to living cells.

questions.question_text: Half-life of a radioactive substance is:

options.text: Time for half the nuclei to decay

questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B. Half-life is the time it takes for half the radioactive nuclei in a sample to decay. This means that after one half-life, half the original nuclei will have decayed, and after two half-lives, a quarter of the original nuclei will remain, and so on.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because they do not accurately describe what half-life means. Option A is wrong because half-life does not refer to the time for complete decay, which can take much longer. Option C is wrong because half-life is not half the decay time. Option D is wrong because half-life is the time for half the nuclei to decay, not the time for the activity to double.

questions.question_text: Nuclear fission is:

options.text: Splitting heavy nucleus into lighter nuclei

questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) Splitting heavy nucleus into lighter nuclei. Nuclear fission is the process where a heavy nucleus like Uranium-235 splits into two or more lighter nuclei, releasing a lot of energy in the process.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nuclear fission is not the same as combining light nuclei, which is known as nuclear fusion. Nuclear fission involves splitting heavy nuclei like Uranium, while fusion combines light nuclei like hydrogen to form heavier ones. Fission is the process used in nuclear reactors to generate electricity, not the emission of alpha or gamma radiation.

questions.question_text: Nuclear fusion is:

options.text: Combining light nuclei to form heavier nucleus

questions.explanation_correct: Nuclear fusion is the process of combining light nuclei, such as hydrogen, to form a heavier nucleus, like helium. This is the source of energy in the Sun and other stars, and it releases a large amount of energy in the process.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nuclear fusion is the opposite of nuclear fission, which is the splitting of heavy nuclei like uranium. In nuclear fusion, light nuclei are combined to form a heavier nucleus, releasing a large amount of energy. This is the process that powers the Sun and other stars, not the splitting of heavy nuclei.

questions.question_text: The source of energy in the sun is:
questions.explanation_correct: The source of energy in the sun is nuclear fusion, where light nuclei like hydrogen are combined to form heavier nuclei like helium, releasing a huge amount of energy in the process. This is the reason why the sun shines and provides the Earth with energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nuclear fission, the splitting of heavy nuclei, is not the source of the sun's energy. Chemical reactions and radioactive decay also do not provide enough energy to power the sun for billions of years. The sun's energy comes from the nuclear fusion of hydrogen into helium, which occurs at the sun's core under extremely high temperature and pressure conditions.

questions.question_text: Alpha particles can be stopped by:
questions.explanation_correct: Alpha particles have very little penetrating power and can be easily stopped by a thin sheet of paper. This is because they are the heaviest type of radiation, consisting of helium nuclei, and quickly lose their energy when passing through matter.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Alpha particles are not able to penetrate thick lead or concrete walls, as these materials are too dense and would completely block them. Similarly, a vacuum would not stop alpha particles, as they need to interact with matter to lose their energy. Only a thin sheet of paper is sufficient to stop the relatively low-penetrating alpha radiation.

questions.question_text: Beta particles can be stopped by:
questions.explanation_correct: Beta particles can be stopped by a thin aluminum sheet because their moderate penetrating power means they are stopped by a relatively thin material, unlike the more penetrating gamma rays or less penetrating alpha particles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Beta particles cannot be stopped by just paper, which is too thin, or nothing at all. They can be stopped by a thin sheet of aluminum, which is denser and provides enough material to absorb and stop the beta particles. Lead is not required to stop beta particles, as it is used to stop the more penetrating gamma rays.

questions.question_text: Isotopes have:

options.text: Same mass number, different atomic number
Same atomic number, different mass number

questions.explanation_correct: Isotopes have the same atomic number (number of protons) but different mass numbers (total number of protons and neutrons). This means they have the same chemical properties but different physical properties like mass.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Isotopes do not have the same mass number and atomic number. Atoms with the same atomic number but different mass numbers are called isotopes. For example, Carbon-12 and Carbon-13 are isotopes of carbon because they both have 6 protons (atomic number) but different numbers of neutrons (mass numbers).

questions.question_text: If half-life of a substance is 10 years, after 30 years the remaining fraction is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is C) 1/8. This is because the half-life of a substance is the time it takes for half of the radioactive atoms to decay. After 30 years (3 half-lives), the remaining fraction would be 1/2 x 1/2 x 1/2 = 1/8.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answers are: A) 1/2 - This would be the case after only 10 years (1 half-life), not 30 years. B) 1/4 - This would be the case after 20 years (2 half-lives), not 30 years. D) 1/16 - This would be the case after 40 years (4 half-lives), not 30 years.

questions.question_text: In nuclear fission, the fuel commonly used is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is C) Uranium-235 because in nuclear fission, heavy nuclei like uranium-235 are split to release energy and neutrons, which is the common process used in nuclear reactors.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Uranium-235 is the correct fuel used in nuclear fission, not hydrogen, helium, or carbon. Hydrogen and helium are light elements that undergo nuclear fusion, the process of combining light nuclei, which is the source of the Sun's energy. Carbon is a solid element that does not participate in nuclear reactions in the same way as uranium-235.

questions.question_text: A chain reaction in nuclear fission is sustained when:

options.text: At least one neutron from each fission causes another fission

questions.explanation_correct: A chain reaction in nuclear fission is sustained when at least one neutron from each fission causes another fission. This is because the neutrons released from fission can split other heavy nuclei, releasing more neutrons to continue the chain reaction and release energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B) At least one neutron from each fission causes another fission. This is because the chain reaction needs the neutrons released from fission to split other heavy nuclei and continue the reaction. The other options are incorrect - option A) would mean no new fissions can occur, option C) would mean the neutrons escape without causing further fissions, and option D) a temperature drop would actually slow down the chain reaction.

questions.question_text: Nuclear reactor produces electricity by:
questions.explanation_correct: A nuclear reactor produces electricity through controlled nuclear fission. In nuclear fission, the heavy nuclei of uranium (U-235) are split apart, releasing energy and more neutrons that can split other uranium nuclei in a chain reaction. This controlled nuclear fission process is used to generate heat, which is then used to produce steam and drive turbines to generate electricity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nuclear fusion, where light nuclei like hydrogen combine to form heavier nuclei like helium, is the source of energy in the Sun and other stars, but it is not the process used in a nuclear reactor to generate electricity. The reactor also does not produce electricity through a chemical reaction or by simply burning uranium. Instead, the reactor uses the controlled splitting of uranium nuclei, or nuclear fission, to generate the heat and energy needed to produce electricity.

questions.question_text: Control rods in nuclear reactor are made of:
questions.explanation_correct: Control rods in nuclear reactors are made of materials like cadmium or boron because these elements can easily absorb neutrons. This helps control the nuclear fission reaction by absorbing excess neutrons and slowing down the chain reaction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Control rods are not made of uranium, as uranium is the fuel that undergoes nuclear fission in the reactor. They also do not contain carbon or lead, as these materials are not as effective in absorbing neutrons to control the reaction.

questions.question_text: When an alpha particle is emitted, the atomic number:
questions.explanation_correct: When an alpha particle is emitted, the atomic number of the nucleus decreases by 2. This is because an alpha particle consists of two protons and two neutrons, which are emitted from the nucleus, reducing the number of protons in the nucleus by two and thus decreasing the atomic number.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because: B) Increasing the atomic number by 2 would mean the nucleus is gaining protons, which is not the case for alpha decay. C) The atomic number cannot remain the same, as it must decrease by 2 when an alpha particle is emitted. D) Decreasing the atomic number by 4 is incorrect, as the decrease is only by 2 for alpha decay.

questions.question_text: When a beta particle is emitted, the atomic number:
questions.explanation_correct: When a beta particle (electron) is emitted from the nucleus, the atomic number increases by 1 because the number of protons in the nucleus increases by 1. This is because the beta particle comes from the conversion of a neutron into a proton, electron, and an antineutrino.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because the atomic number decreases by 1 when an alpha particle (helium nucleus) is emitted, not a beta particle. Option C is incorrect because the atomic number must change when a radioactive decay occurs. Option D is incorrect because the atomic number decreases by 2 when an alpha particle is emitted, not a beta particle.

questions.question_text: Carbon dating is used to determine:
questions.explanation_correct: Carbon dating is used to determine the age of archaeological artifacts, such as bones, wood, and other organic materials. This is because radioactive carbon-14 is present in all living things and decays at a known rate after they die, allowing the age of the artifact to be calculated.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Carbon dating is not used to determine the age of rocks, as rocks do not contain significant amounts of radioactive carbon-14. It is also not used to determine the composition of carbon or the temperature of objects. Carbon dating is a technique used specifically to measure the age of archaeological artifacts made from once-living materials.

questions.question_text: Critical mass is:

options.text: Minimum mass required for sustained chain reaction

questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) Minimum mass required for sustained chain reaction. In a nuclear reactor, the critical mass is the minimum amount of fissile material (such as U-235) needed to sustain a nuclear chain reaction. This is the minimum mass required for the reactor to continue operating without the reaction dying out.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect. Option A) Maximum mass of fuel is not correct, as the critical mass is the minimum, not maximum, mass needed. Option C) Mass of one atom is also wrong, as the critical mass refers to the total amount of material, not a single atom. Option D) Mass of control rod is incorrect, as the control rods are used to regulate the chain reaction, not define the critical mass.

questions.question_text: A major hazard of nuclear power plants is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) Radioactive waste disposal. Nuclear power plants generate highly radioactive waste, which is a major hazard that needs to be safely stored and disposed of to prevent environmental contamination and harm to living beings.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not the major hazards of nuclear power plants. High temperature and high pressure are common in any power plant, not just nuclear ones. Noise pollution is not a significant hazard for nuclear power plants. The main hazard is the radioactive waste that is produced, which must be carefully handled and disposed of to avoid harmful radiation exposure.

questions.question_text: The nucleus contains:
questions.explanation_correct: The nucleus of an atom contains both protons and neutrons. Protons have a positive charge and neutrons have no charge. Together, they make up the dense, central part of the atom.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The nucleus does not contain just protons or just neutrons. It contains both protons and neutrons. Protons have a positive charge and are responsible for the atom's overall positive charge, while neutrons have no charge. The combination of protons and neutrons in the nucleus is what gives an atom its unique properties.

questions.question_text: Nuclear fusion requires very high temperature because:

options.text: To overcome electrostatic repulsion between nuclei

questions.explanation_correct: Nuclear fusion requires very high temperature because the positively charged nuclei must overcome the electrostatic repulsion between them in order to fuse and form a new, heavier nucleus. This high temperature provides the energy needed to push the nuclei close enough together for the strong nuclear force to take over and allow fusion to occur.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is that nuclear fusion requires very high temperature to overcome the electrostatic repulsion between the positively charged nuclei. The other options are incorrect - fusion does release heat, but this is a result of the fusion process, not the reason it requires high temperature. Slowing down neutrons and absorbing gamma rays are not directly relevant to the conditions needed for nuclear fusion to take place.

questions.question_text: Radioactive tracers are used in:
questions.explanation_correct: Radioactive tracers are used in medical diagnosis because they emit radiation that can be detected and used to track the location and concentration of specific substances in the body, allowing doctors to diagnose and monitor various medical conditions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Radioactive tracers are not used in power generation, bomb making, or cleaning. They are specifically used in medical diagnosis to help doctors detect and monitor health issues by tracking the movement and concentration of radioactive materials in the body. The radioactive emissions from the tracers can be detected and used to provide important information for diagnosis and treatment.

questions.question_text: After 4 half-lives, the remaining radioactive material is:
questions.explanation_correct: After 4 half-lives, the remaining radioactive material is 1/16 of the original amount. This is because each half-life reduces the radioactive material by half, so after 4 half-lives, it is reduced to 1/2 x 1/2 x 1/2 x 1/2 = 1/16 of the original amount.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is C) 1/16. This is because each half-life reduces the radioactive material by half. After the first half-life, 1/2 of the original amount remains. After the second half-life, 1/4 of the original amount remains. After the third half-life, 1/8 of the original amount remains. And after the fourth half-life, 1/16 of the original amount remains. Options A) 1/4 and B) 1/8 are incorrect because they do not account for the full 4 half-lives.

questions.question_text: The moderator in a nuclear reactor:
questions.explanation_correct: The moderator in a nuclear reactor slows down neutrons. This helps to maintain the chain reaction in the reactor by ensuring that the neutrons have the right speed to be absorbed by the fissile nuclei and cause further fissions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The moderator in a nuclear reactor is not meant to speed up neutrons, absorb all neutrons, or produce neutrons. Its main function is to slow down the high-energy neutrons released during fission, so that they can be more likely to be absorbed by the fissile nuclei and continue the chain reaction. Slowing down the neutrons is crucial for the sustained operation of a nuclear reactor.

questions.question_text: Mass number (A) is equal to:
questions.explanation_correct: The mass number (A) is the total number of protons and neutrons in the nucleus of an atom. This is because the mass of an atom is primarily determined by the mass of its protons and neutrons, not the electrons, which have a much smaller mass.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The mass number (A) is not equal to the number of protons, the number of neutrons, or the number of electrons in an atom. The mass number is the sum of the number of protons and the number of neutrons in the nucleus of an atom. The number of electrons is not included in the mass number, as the mass of electrons is much smaller compared to the mass of protons and neutrons.

questions.question_text: Gamma emission does not change:
questions.explanation_correct: Gamma emission does not change the atomic number or mass number of the nucleus because it only involves the release of excess energy from the nucleus, without any change in the number of protons or neutrons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gamma emission is a type of radioactive decay where the nucleus releases excess energy in the form of high-energy electromagnetic radiation, without ejecting any particles. This means that the number of protons (atomic number) and the number of protons and neutrons (mass number) remain the same after gamma emission. Options A and B are incorrect because they suggest that gamma emission changes either the atomic number or the mass number, which is not the case.

questions.question_text: Radioactivity is a nuclear phenomenon.
questions.explanation_correct: Radioactivity is indeed a nuclear phenomenon. It involves the spontaneous emission of radiation from the nuclei of unstable atoms, which is a process happening at the atomic level within the nucleus.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Radioactivity is not a chemical phenomenon. It does not involve the rearrangement of electrons around the nucleus, which is what happens in chemical reactions. Radioactivity is specifically a nuclear process where the nucleus of an atom is undergoing changes and emitting radiation.

questions.question_text: Alpha particles are positively charged.
questions.explanation_correct: Alpha particles are positively charged because they are made up of two protons and two neutrons, which together make up the nucleus of a helium atom. This gives the alpha particle a positive charge of +2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement that alpha particles are positively charged is true. Alpha particles consist of two protons and two neutrons, which together make up the nucleus of a helium atom. This gives the alpha particle a positive charge of +2. Some students may have thought that alpha particles are negatively charged, but that is not the case.

questions.question_text: Gamma rays are deflected by magnetic field.
questions.explanation_correct: Gamma rays are uncharged electromagnetic radiation, so they are not affected by magnetic fields. This is because magnetic fields only exert forces on charged particles, not on neutral particles like gamma rays.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Gamma rays are uncharged, meaning they do not carry any electric charge. Charged particles like electrons and alpha particles can be deflected by magnetic fields, but gamma rays cannot be deflected because they have no charge. Gamma rays travel in a straight line, unaffected by magnetic fields.

questions.question_text: Nuclear fusion releases more energy per unit mass than fission.
questions.explanation_correct: Nuclear fusion, which combines light nuclei like hydrogen into heavier nuclei like helium, releases more energy per unit mass than nuclear fission, which splits heavy nuclei like uranium. This is because the products of fusion have a lower mass than the original light nuclei, with the mass difference converted into a large amount of energy according to Einstein's E=mc^2 equation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer assumes that fission, which splits heavy nuclei, releases more energy per unit mass than fusion, which combines light nuclei. However, this is not the case. Fusion reactions actually release much more energy per unit mass compared to fission reactions, because the products of fusion have a lower mass than the original light nuclei, with the mass difference converted into a large amount of energy.

questions.question_text: Half-life of a radioactive substance can be changed by heating.
questions.explanation_correct: The half-life of a radioactive substance is the time it takes for half of the radioactive atoms to decay. This is a fundamental property of the atoms and is not affected by factors like temperature or pressure. Heating the substance will not change its half-life.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The half-life of a radioactive substance is a fixed property that depends on the type of radioactive atoms and cannot be changed. Heating the substance may speed up the motion of the atoms, but it does not change the rate at which the unstable nuclei undergo radioactive decay. The half-life remains the same regardless of the temperature.

questions.question_text: Nuclear power plants produce greenhouse gases during operation.
questions.explanation_correct: Nuclear power plants do not produce greenhouse gases during operation. They generate electricity through the process of nuclear fission, which does not involve the burning of fossil fuels that release greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is a common misconception, but nuclear power plants do not produce greenhouse gases during their operation. The nuclear fission process used in power plants generates electricity without burning any fossil fuels, which are the main source of greenhouse gas emissions. The only emissions from nuclear power plants are non-greenhouse gases like water vapor.

questions.question_text: Nuclear fusion is used in nuclear power plants today.
questions.explanation_correct: Nuclear fusion is the process of combining light nuclei to form heavier nuclei, releasing a large amount of energy. This process powers the Sun and other stars, but it is not currently used in commercial nuclear power plants on Earth. Nuclear power plants today use the process of nuclear fission, where heavy nuclei are split to release energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nuclear fusion is not yet used in commercial nuclear power plants today. While fusion is the process that powers the Sun and other stars, the technology to harness fusion on Earth for electricity generation is still under development. Most nuclear power plants today use nuclear fission, where heavy nuclei are split to release energy, rather than fusion.

questions.question_text: Beta particles are deflected in opposite direction to alpha particles in a magnetic field.
questions.explanation_correct: Beta particles are electrons, which have a negative charge. In a magnetic field, they will be deflected in the opposite direction to positively charged alpha particles (helium nuclei).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect statement is that beta particles are deflected in the opposite direction to alpha particles in a magnetic field. This is not true. Beta particles are actually deflected in the same direction as alpha particles in a magnetic field, because both are charged particles. The difference is that beta particles have a negative charge, while alpha particles have a positive charge.

questions.question_text: Atomic number equals the number of protons.
questions.explanation_correct: The atomic number of an element is equal to the number of protons in the nucleus of its atoms. This is a fundamental property of an element that defines its chemical identity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The number of protons in an atom's nucleus is not the same as the atomic number. The atomic number is a unique identifier for each element, representing the number of protons. For example, the element hydrogen has 1 proton, so its atomic number is 1.

questions.question_text: Cobalt-60 is used in radiation therapy for cancer treatment.
questions.explanation_correct: Cobalt-60 is a radioactive isotope that emits high-energy gamma rays, which are used in radiation therapy to destroy cancer cells. This makes Cobalt-60 an important tool in the treatment of certain types of cancer, making the statement true.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cobalt-60 is not used in radiation therapy. The statement is correct because Cobalt-60 is a radioactive isotope that emits high-energy gamma rays, which are used to destroy cancer cells during radiation therapy. This makes it a valuable tool in the treatment of certain types of cancer.

questions.question_text: Radioactivity was discovered by ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Radioactivity was discovered by Becquerel in 1896. He found that uranium salts could emit their own invisible and penetrating rays, which was a new and unexpected property of matter at that time.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'Becquerel'. Radioactivity was not discovered by other scientists like Marie Curie or Ernest Rutherford, but by Henri Becquerel, a French physicist, who made this important discovery in 1896. Becquerel's work on radioactivity laid the foundations for the field of nuclear physics.

questions.question_text: Alpha particles are ___ nuclei.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is 'helium' because alpha particles are actually helium nuclei, which have 2 protons and 2 neutrons in their nucleus. This makes them the nuclei of the helium atom.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'helium'. Alpha particles are not just any nuclei, but specifically helium nuclei. They have 2 protons and 2 neutrons, which gives them a positive charge of +2. This makes them distinct from other types of radioactive emissions like beta particles (electrons) and gamma rays (electromagnetic radiation).

questions.question_text: Beta particles are high-speed ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Beta particles are high-speed electrons emitted from the nucleus during radioactive decay. This is because the nucleus is unstable and ejects an electron (a beta particle) to achieve a more stable configuration.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format for this fill-in-the-blank question is 'electrons'. Beta particles are not protons, neutrons, or other particles - they are high-speed electrons emitted from the nucleus during radioactive decay. This is because the nucleus is unstable and ejects an electron to become more stable.

questions.question_text: ___ rays have the highest penetrating power among radioactive emissions.
questions.explanation_correct: Gamma rays have the highest penetrating power among the three types of radioactive emissions (alpha, beta, and gamma) because they have no electric charge and travel at the speed of light. This allows them to pass through most materials more easily compared to the heavier and slower alpha and beta particles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'Gamma'. Gamma rays are the most penetrating type of radioactive emission because they have no electric charge and travel at the speed of light. Alpha particles have a positive charge and are the least penetrating, while beta particles are negatively charged electrons that have moderate penetrating power compared to alpha and gamma.

questions.question_text: The time for half the radioactive nuclei to decay is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The time for half the radioactive nuclei to decay is called the half-life. This is because after one half-life, half of the original radioactive atoms will have decayed, leaving the other half remaining.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'half-life'. This refers to the time it takes for half of the radioactive nuclei in a sample to decay. It is an important concept in radioactivity, as it allows us to predict how the amount of a radioactive substance will decrease over time.

questions.question_text: Nuclear ___ is the splitting of heavy nucleus into lighter nuclei.
questions.explanation_correct: Nuclear fission is the correct answer because it refers to the splitting of heavy nuclei, such as Uranium-235, into lighter nuclei. This process releases a large amount of energy, which is used in nuclear power plants to generate electricity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'fission'. Nuclear fusion, which is the combining of light nuclei to form heavier nuclei, is not the correct answer here. Fusion is the process that powers the Sun and other stars, while fission is the splitting of heavy nuclei, which is used in nuclear reactors to generate electricity.

questions.question_text: The source of solar energy is nuclear ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The source of solar energy is nuclear fusion, which is the process of combining lighter atomic nuclei, like hydrogen, into heavier nuclei, like helium. This nuclear fusion reaction releases a large amount of energy, which is the source of the Sun's energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'fusion'. The source of solar energy is not nuclear fission, which is the process of splitting heavy atomic nuclei, like uranium, into lighter nuclei. Nuclear fusion, where light nuclei are combined to form heavier nuclei, is the process that powers the Sun and other stars.

questions.question_text: The minimum mass required for sustained chain reaction is called ___ mass.
questions.explanation_correct: The minimum mass required for a sustained nuclear chain reaction to occur is called the critical mass. This is because the critical mass is the minimum amount of fissile material needed to maintain a self-sustaining nuclear reaction, where the number of neutrons produced by fission is equal to the number of neutrons absorbed or lost.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format for this fill-in-the-blank question is 'critical'. The critical mass is the minimum amount of fissile material needed to maintain a self-sustaining nuclear chain reaction. This is because the critical mass ensures that the number of neutrons produced by fission is equal to the number of neutrons absorbed or lost, allowing the reaction to continue indefinitely.

questions.question_text: ___ rods absorb neutrons to control chain reaction in a reactor.
questions.explanation_correct: Control rods are made of materials that absorb neutrons, like boron or cadmium. By moving the control rods in and out of the reactor core, the number of neutrons available for the chain reaction can be controlled, allowing the reactor power to be adjusted as needed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is a single word: 'Control'. The incorrect answer would be something like 'Fuel' rods, which provide the fissile material (like uranium) for the nuclear reaction, but do not control the reaction rate. Control rods are the key component that allows the chain reaction in a nuclear reactor to be regulated and kept stable.

questions.question_text: In alpha decay, mass number decreases by ___.
questions.explanation_correct: In alpha decay, the atomic nucleus emits an alpha particle, which is a helium nucleus (2 protons and 2 neutrons). As a result, the mass number of the nucleus decreases by 4, since 2 protons and 2 neutrons are lost.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is a single number. The mass number decreases by 4 in alpha decay because the nucleus loses an alpha particle, which has 2 protons and 2 neutrons. So the total mass number decreases by 4. Simply writing '4' is the correct answer here.

questions.question_text: Carbon-14 dating is used to find the age of ___ artifacts.
questions.explanation_correct: Carbon-14 dating is used to determine the age of archaeological artifacts, such as fossils and ancient human remains. This is because carbon-14 is a radioactive isotope that is present in all living things and decays at a known rate, allowing scientists to estimate the age of the artifacts based on the amount of carbon-14 remaining.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format for this question is 'archaeological'. This is because carbon-14 dating is used to determine the age of ancient artifacts, such as fossils and human remains, not modern artifacts. The process of carbon-14 dating relies on the radioactive decay of the carbon-14 isotope, which is present in all living things and can be used to estimate the age of organic materials.

questions.question_text: Atoms with same atomic number but different mass numbers are called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Atoms with the same atomic number but different mass numbers are called isotopes. This is because the atomic number, which represents the number of protons, is the same, but the mass number, which represents the total number of protons and neutrons, is different. Isotopes of an element have the same chemical properties but may have different physical properties.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'isotopes'. Isotopes are atoms of the same element that have the same number of protons but different numbers of neutrons, resulting in different mass numbers. This means they have the same atomic number but different mass numbers, which is the key characteristic of isotopes. Other terms like 'isomers' or 'isotones' do not correctly describe atoms with the same atomic number but different mass numbers.

questions.question_text: Arrange the radioactive emissions in order of increasing penetrating power:
questions.explanation_correct: Alpha particles have the least penetrating power, followed by beta particles, and gamma rays have the highest penetrating power. This is because alpha particles are the heaviest and have the most charge, beta particles are lighter and have less charge, while gamma rays are electromagnetic radiation with no charge and can easily pass through matter.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The order of increasing penetrating power is not alpha, beta, gamma. Alpha particles are actually the least penetrating, followed by beta particles, and gamma rays are the most penetrating. This is because alpha particles are large and have a lot of charge, so they interact strongly with matter and get absorbed quickly. Beta particles are smaller and have less charge, so they can penetrate further. Gamma rays have no charge and are just high-energy electromagnetic radiation, so they can travel the farthest through materials.

questions.question_text: Arrange the radioactive emissions in order of increasing ionizing power:
questions.explanation_correct: Gamma rays have the highest ionizing power, followed by beta particles and then alpha particles. This is because gamma rays are high-energy electromagnetic radiation that can easily penetrate and ionize atoms, beta particles are fast-moving electrons, and alpha particles have the largest mass and charge which makes them the least penetrating.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The order of increasing ionizing power is actually gamma rays, beta particles, and then alpha particles. Gamma rays have the highest ionizing power because they are high-energy electromagnetic radiation that can easily penetrate and ionize atoms. Beta particles, being fast-moving electrons, have a moderate ionizing power. Alpha particles have the largest mass and charge, making them the least penetrating and therefore the lowest in ionizing power.

questions.question_text: Arrange the steps in a nuclear fission chain reaction:
ordering_items: Nucleus splits releasing energy and neutrons
correct_answer: Nucleus splits releasing energy and neutrons
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is: Neutron hits U-235 nucleus, Nucleus splits releasing energy and neutrons, Neutrons hit other nuclei, More fissions occur. This is the basic sequence of a nuclear fission chain reaction, where the splitting of one U-235 nucleus releases neutrons that can split other U-235 nuclei, creating a self-sustaining chain reaction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be: Neutrons hit other nuclei, Neutron hits U-235 nucleus, Nucleus splits releasing energy and neutrons, More fissions occur. This is incorrect because the chain reaction starts with a neutron hitting a U-235 nucleus, causing it to split and release more neutrons, which then go on to hit other U-235 nuclei, leading to more fissions and a self-sustaining chain reaction.

questions.question_text: Arrange these fractions of remaining radioactive material by number of half-lives (least to most half-lives):
questions.explanation_correct: The number of half-lives corresponds to the fraction of remaining radioactive material. After 1 half-life, 1/2 of the material remains. After 2 half-lives, 1/4 remains. After 3 half-lives, 1/8 remains. After 4 half-lives, 1/16 remains. So the correct order from least to most half-lives is: 1/2 (1 half-life), 1/4 (2 half-lives), 1/8 (3 half-lives), 1/16 (4 half-lives).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be to put the fractions in reverse order, from most to least half-lives. This is wrong because each half-life reduces the remaining radioactive material by half. So the fraction with the fewest half-lives should come first, followed by the fractions with more and more half-lives in increasing order.

questions.question_text: Arrange the materials that can stop each radiation (weakest to strongest barrier needed):
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is paper for alpha, aluminum for beta, and lead for gamma, because alpha particles have the least penetrating power, gamma rays have the most penetrating power, and beta particles are in the middle. Paper can easily stop the weakest alpha particles, aluminum can stop the more penetrating beta particles, and lead is required to stop the highly penetrating gamma rays.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be aluminum for alpha, paper for beta, and lead for gamma. This is wrong because alpha particles are the least penetrating and can be stopped by a thin sheet of paper, beta particles have moderate penetrating power and need aluminum to be stopped, and gamma rays are the most penetrating and require a thick layer of lead to be blocked effectively.
